DOC.HEADLINE: NZ mulls over stopping Japan 's whale slaughter in World Court

TEXT.P: New Zealand is seeking all options including a possible legal fight against Japan's plan to kill endangered humpback whales, local media said Monday.
Conservation Minister Chris Carter told NZPA, a news agency, that he understands the Japanese want to add 80 of each of hampback and fin whales to its legal kill lists.

Japan plans to go to the meeting of the International Whaling Commission (IWC) in South Korea in June asking to double its kill of about 440 minke whales a year for so-called scientific purposes, and also add humpback and fin whales to the list.
Carter, who is to attend the IWC meeting, said New Zealand is fighting the proposal on a number of counts, and taking a case to the World Court is one option.
Green Party co-leader Jeanette Fitzsimons said only words are not enough to stop Japan's plans for the slaughter and the New Zealand "Government must take serious action against Japan."
Challenging the plans in the World Court should be considered, said Fitzsimons.
"The humpback whale was almost hunted into extinction. We cannot allow it to become a target for Japanese harpoon guns," she said.
